childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1984-1996

The click of a View-Master reel advancing. The chemical smell of Scratch 'n Sniff stickers. The satisfying crunch of a Fruit Roll-Up peeled from its plastic backing. Growing up in the mid-1980s meant childhood had a texture that screens can't replicate—everything was tactile, immediate, real.

At two, the Challenger exploded, and children absorbed adult grief without understanding it. At five, the Berlin Wall fell, and children watched crowds with sledgehammers on a TV they weren't supposed to be watching. At seven, the Soviet Union dissolved, and the Cold War their parents had lived under their entire lives just... ended. Children didn't appreciate what that meant. They were busy with their Ninja Turtles.

Toys were serious business. Transformers that actually transformed—Optimus Prime, Megatron, Soundwave with his cassette minions. He-Man and the Masters of the Universe. She-Ra for the girls who got tired of Barbie's career changes. G.I. Joe with the file cards on the back memorized like baseball statistics. My Little Ponies with brushable hair that sisters would kill them for touching.

Saturday mornings were sacred. Children woke before their parents, poured themselves a bowl of Cookie Crisp or Fruity Pebbles, and planted themselves in front of the TV for four solid hours. The Smurfs, Muppet Babies, Pee-wee's Playhouse, then the Disney Afternoon block—DuckTales, Chip 'n Dale Rescue Rangers, TaleSpin. By the time parents shuffled out for coffee, children had absorbed more content than parents realized existed.

Friday nights meant Blockbuster. That specific smell—carpet cleaner and plastic VHS cases. Running fingers along the spines in the New Releases section, hoping nobody had taken The Land Before Time or The Princess Bride. The backup movie that sometimes turned out better than the first choice. Microwave popcorn with too much fake butter. Whole families on one couch, watching together, because there was only one TV and no one had anywhere else to be.

Children ate Lunchables with the pizza kind being premium. Dunkaroos rationed so the frosting lasted. Gushers that promised to turn heads into fruit. Hi-C Ecto Cooler in the green box with Slimer on it—siblings would fight for the last one. At eleven, Princess Diana died, and children watched 2.5 billion people mourn someone they'd never met. They didn't understand parasocial grief then. They understand it now.

generational_identity.html:
The Millennial Generation

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996. The word became a punchline before this cohort hit thirty—shorthand for entitled, fragile, participation-trophy collectors who ruined everything from napkins to the diamond industry. Never mind that they're the most educated generation in American history. Never mind that they played by every rule and still got handed a collapsing economy. The narrative was written before they got a chance to speak.

This generation was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} on September 11, 2001—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. They remember the classroom, the teacher's face, the moment someone wheeled in the TV. They watched the second plane hit live. They watched the towers fall. The before and after of that morning split their adolescence in two. Before: Y2K parties, Napster downloads, the promise of a new millennium. After: orange terror alerts, endless wars, shoes off at airports forever.

This generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. They're the largest living generation, though Gen Z is gaining. They were promised that hard work and education would guarantee success. They got the degrees, took the internships, did everything right. Then they graduated into a crater.

The 2008 financial crisis hit when this cohort was {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}. Not fresh out of college but not established either—that brutal middle ground where they'd just started to feel stable. Jobs evaporated. The housing market imploded. Their parents' retirement accounts vanished. They learned, viscerally, that the system wasn't designed to catch them when it failed.

This cohort is sandwiched between Gen X (who bought houses when houses cost what cars cost now) and Gen Z (who never expected stability in the first place). They still believe, somewhere deep down, that reform is possible. They're not sure why they still believe that. But they do.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Ghostbusters came out in 1984—Bill Murray deadpanning while fighting supernatural slime, spawning a franchise that would define toy boxes. The Terminator promised he'd be back, and he was, when this cohort was seven, with a sequel that made 'Hasta la vista, baby' the most-quoted line in elementary schools. Beverly Hills Cop made Eddie Murphy the biggest star on the planet. Footloose convinced America that dancing in a barn was revolutionary.

Prince's Purple Rain wasn't just an album—it was a cultural event. Parents saw it in theaters. Children would hear 'When Doves Cry' at weddings for the rest of their lives. Madonna emerged that year with 'Like a Virgin,' scandalizing parents everywhere while their kids memorized every word. Van Halen's 'Jump' was inescapable. Bruce Springsteen's 'Born in the U.S.A.' became the most misunderstood anthem in rock history—people heard the chorus and missed the protest.

Actual pop culture education started with the cartoon renaissance. At two, children were watching Transformers transform—Optimus Prime's death in the 1986 movie might be their first memory of betrayal by a storytelling medium. G.I. Joe taught them that knowing was half the battle (the other half was lasers). He-Man declared his power while children mimicked with plastic swords. The Smurfs, Care Bears, Rainbow Brite—toyboxes were merchandising goldmines.

At six, children discovered Nickelodeon's new programming block. Double Dare made them want to get slimed. You Are Here helped them feel less alone. By ten, Rugrats premiered, treating kids like they had actual inner lives. Doug captured the anxious inner monologue of childhood. Ren & Stimpy was too weird for parents to understand but exactly right for children.

High school meant TRL with Carson Daly, the daily countdown that launched boy band careers. Backstreet Boys or *NSYNC—they had to choose sides. Britney vs. Christina. They knew all the moves to 'Bye Bye Bye' even if they'd never admit it now. The Macarena at every school dance until they wanted to scream. 'Who Let the Dogs Out' on infinite loop.

Then emo arrived. Dashboard Confessional made crying seem sophisticated. Fall Out Boy song titles were longer than the songs themselves. My Chemical Romance made black clothes and eyeliner mandatory. MySpace profiles had auto-playing songs—something by Taking Back Sunday or The Used that perfectly captured seventeen-year-old angst. Hours spent ranking Top 8, knowing the social consequences of every placement.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

Apple launched the Macintosh in 1984. January 24, 1984. The '1984' Super Bowl commercial—the one with the sledgehammer through Big Brother's screen—premiered two days before. This cohort arrived into a world where personal computers were exotic, expensive, and mostly useless for anyone who didn't program. They'd watch them become everything.

At four, families might have had a VCR—the kind with the flashing 12:00 nobody knew how to fix. At six, children played their first Nintendo games: Super Mario Bros., Duck Hunt with the plastic gun that only worked if they stood close enough. The NES was magic. They begged for new cartridges. They learned to blow on them when they wouldn't load.

At seven, children heard the sound that would define their adolescent internet: the dial-up handshake. That screech-and-static meant they were about to wait three minutes for a single image to load while nobody in the house could use the phone. AOL discs arrived in the mail constantly. First screen names were probably embarrassing—something with numbers because preferred names were taken.

At eleven, Windows 95 changed everything. That startup sound. The rolling hills wallpaper. Solitaire and Minesweeper for hours because there wasn't much else to do yet. The CD-ROM games: Oregon Trail (they died of dysentery), Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego, Encarta Encyclopedia with its videos that took forever to buffer.

AIM arrived when this cohort was thirteen. A buddy list organized by social hierarchy. Away messages crafted like poetry—song lyrics meant something. The door-opening sound when a crush came online. The agony of deciding whether to message first. 'brb,' 'lol,' 'ttyl'—they developed a language parents couldn't decode.

At sixteen, Napster. Suddenly every song ever recorded was free, if they were willing to wait four hours and risk viruses. They learned to steal music before they could legally buy it. LimeWire after Napster died. Burned CDs with handwritten tracklists. At nineteen, the iPod put 1,000 songs in pockets. At twenty, Facebook required a .edu email and parents didn't know it existed. At twenty-three, the iPhone dropped, and everything before it suddenly looked prehistoric.

This is the last generation that remembers life before the internet was in their pocket. They know what it's like to be truly bored, with nothing to scroll. They can read a map, use a card catalog, remember phone numbers. These are superpowers now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The Challenger exploded in January 1986. Christa McAuliffe was going to be the first teacher in space, and classrooms across America watched live as the shuttle broke apart seventy-three seconds after launch. This cohort was too young to understand, but they absorbed the grief around them—the first national trauma they experienced without comprehending.

At five, the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989. Parents remember exactly where they were—crowds with sledgehammers, champagne, strangers embracing. The Cold War that had defined their entire lives ended in a single night of celebration. For this cohort, it was images on a TV they weren't supposed to be watching past bedtime. They didn't understand the stakes. Parents had spent decades afraid of nuclear annihilation. Children just saw a party.

At seven, the Soviet Union dissolved. The hammer and sickle came down. The 'evil empire' their parents' generation had grown up fearing simply ceased to exist. The world was supposed to be safer now. History was supposed to be over. That narrative lasted about a decade.

At eleven, Oklahoma City. April 19, 1995. Domestic terrorism before they had the vocabulary. 168 people dead, including nineteen children in a daycare. This cohort was in sixth grade. Adults couldn't explain it because they didn't understand it either. This was Americans killing Americans, and nothing in the script prepared anyone for that.

At fifteen, Columbine. April 20, 1999. This cohort was in ninth grade. They probably didn't watch it live—they were in school—but they felt the aftermath. The lockdown drills started. The clear backpacks. The constant low-grade fear that their school could be next. Something fundamental shifted: school wasn't automatically safe anymore.

September 11, 2001 happened when this cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}. They already know where they were—the classroom, the teacher's face, the TV getting wheeled in. That moment forged this generation's identity in a way nothing else could. The wars that followed—Afghanistan, then Iraq—began during their senior year and were still going when they turned thirty.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the financial system collapsed. This cohort was in college or just out, watching the job market evaporate. At thirty-one, marriage equality became law. At thirty-two, Trump won. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world. This generation has lived through so many 'unprecedented' events that the word has lost meaning. They're numb to it now.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

College graduation came around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}}, give or take. This cohort had maybe two years of normal job market before the 2008 financial crisis incinerated everything. If they were lucky, they'd found their footing. If they weren't, they graduated directly into the worst economy since the Great Depression. Either way, the rules they'd been promised—work hard, get ahead—turned out to be fiction.

The career path of previous generations: graduate, get hired, work forty years, get a pension, retire with dignity. The path for this cohort: graduate, send 200 applications, take unpaid internship for 'experience,' get entry-level job requiring a master's degree, job-hop every two years because that's the only way to get a raise, no pension, no stability, no security, retirement as abstract concept.

The gig economy wasn't built for them—it was built to extract from them. Uber wasn't freedom, it was desperation with a slick app. 'Be your own boss' meant no benefits, no protections, no safety net. 'Passion' became code for 'we won't pay you fairly.' They were told to love what they do so much they'd do it for free. Many did, because there was no alternative.

This cohort has worked in offices with exposed brick and kombucha on tap, where 'unlimited vacation' meant zero vacation because taking time off was career suicide. They've sat through mandatory fun and values workshops and all-hands about culture while executives gave themselves bonuses and laid off departments. They've been told they're 'like family' by organizations that would fire them by email without a second thought.

Wages decoupled from productivity in 1973. The social contract between employer and employee was shredded decades before this generation entered the workforce. They inherited a system where the system was designed to make them believe it was their fault. Not networked enough. Not hustled enough. Not optimized enough. The structure had changed before they sat down.

COVID proved this cohort could work from anywhere, which means now they're expected to work from everywhere, always, Slack pinging at midnight, the laptop on kitchen tables that never fully closes. The boundary between work and life isn't blurred—it's gone.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

The generation that invented modern dating app culture, which is less an invention and more a slow-motion experiment the whole cohort witnessed from inside. Remember when having a crush meant memorizing their class schedule so they could 'accidentally' walk the same hallway? When getting their phone number was a victory, even though calling meant talking to their parents first? When passing a folded note in class felt dangerously intimate?

This generation learned to flirt through AIM away messages. Song lyrics that meant something. 'brb' when they weren't actually leaving—just waiting to see if the other person would say something first. The heartbreak of watching them go idle. The hope when their buddy icon bounced back. The interpretive analysis of whether 'hey' or 'heyy' or 'heyyy' meant something different.

Tinder launched when this cohort was twenty-eight. By then, they'd already had relationships the old-fashioned way—meeting at parties, through friends, in college classes, at bars where they actually talked to strangers. The app changed everything. Suddenly courtship was a sorting algorithm. Swipe right, swipe left, reduce humans to a few photos and a bio. They adapted because that's what they do, but something was lost.

This is the bridge generation in dating. They remember when meeting online was embarrassing, something they'd lie about at weddings. ('We met through friends.') Now it's the default. Their Gen Z cousins have never known anything else. Their parents still don't quite understand how any of it works.

This generation has delayed marriage, not because they don't want partnership, but because the math doesn't work. Average wedding: $30,000. Average house: they can't afford one. Student loans: still paying. The life timeline their parents followed—married by 25, house by 28, kids by 30—isn't available at any price. They're not immature. They're priced out.

Friendships span time zones now. This generation has moved for jobs, for school, for cheaper rent. They maintain relationships through group chats that have been active for a decade, where nobody needs to explain the context because they all lived it together. They know how to stay close to people who are far away. They've had to learn.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three economic collapses before this cohort turned forty. The dot-com bust when they were sixteen—they watched their parents' tech stocks evaporate. The 2008 financial crisis when they were twenty-four—they watched the job market crater just as they needed it. COVID when they were thirty-six—they watched everything shut down, again. Each one taught the same lesson: the floor can disappear at any moment, and there's no safety net waiting.

Previous generations saved because they remembered the Depression. Parents spent because they trusted abundance. This generation saves because they've seen both strategies fail. Their relationship with money isn't rational—it's trauma response dressed up as financial planning.

The ratio is brutal. A median home now costs six times the median income. Previous generations bought houses for two years' salary. They got pensions—actual defined benefits that paid them until they died. This generation got 401(k)s and the advice to 'just invest in index funds' while rent eats 40% of paychecks.

This cohort graduated with an average of $30,000 in student debt—for a degree they were told was mandatory for the middle class. The interest compounds while they make minimum payments because there's nothing left after rent, utilities, health insurance, car payment, groceries. They'll be paying this debt into their forties. Maybe fifties. The math was never mathing.

The avocado toast discourse wasn't just insulting—it was gaslighting. The idea that financial struggles stem from $8 breakfast items, not from housing costs that tripled while wages stayed flat. Previous generations could buy a house on a middle-class salary. This generation cannot. That's not a lifestyle choice. That's math.

This generation has redefined success by necessity. Homeownership isn't the goal—it's a fantasy they've largely abandoned. Retirement at 65 isn't the plan—it's a hope they're not counting on. They're not building generational wealth; they're trying not to become a burden to their kids, if they can afford to have them. Financial security means something different when the system extracts from them instead of building with them.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation's biggest blind spot is the same as its biggest strength: the belief that everything can be optimized. They're so good at adapting that they've forgotten adaptation isn't the goal. They've optimized resumes, LinkedIn profiles, morning routines, sleep scores, macros, meditation minutes. They treat systemic problems as personal productivity challenges. The housing crisis isn't a policy failure—it's a budgeting problem they can spreadsheet their way out of. Except they can't. Some problems don't yield to optimization.

Their coping mechanisms have become invisible to them. They call it self-care when it's actually survival. They call it hustle culture when it's actually exploitation they've accepted. They've normalized things that should be outrageous: healthcare tied to employment, education requiring debt, retirement as fantasy. The water they swim in is toxic, and they've stopped noticing the taste.

Irony is their native language, and it's limiting them. They can't just like something—they have to like it ironically, or critique it while consuming it, or distance themselves with a self-deprecating joke. Earnestness feels dangerous. Advocacy feels cringe. They hedge everything because sincerity makes them vulnerable. This makes it hard to fight for what they actually want.

This cohort is conflict-averse in ways that cost them. They've been trained to be team players, to bring solutions not problems, to never rock the boat. They'll accept 'that's just how it is' as an explanation. They'll endure toxic workplaces because the job market is brutal and they need health insurance. They've mistaken accommodation for maturity.

The digital world feels like action, but it's often just performance. They can mobilize for causes on Twitter, but voter turnout in local elections—where policy actually changes—lags far behind the engagement metrics. They can cancel celebrities, but changing zoning laws requires showing up to boring city council meetings. The dopamine hit of righteous posting isn't the same as power.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: they blame themselves. They've internalized the narrative so thoroughly that they forget to question who wrote it. The self-improvement industry thrives because it's easier to sell them a fix than to fix the system. They've spent so long optimizing themselves that they've forgotten to ask why the optimization is necessary. The benchmarks keep moving. At some point, they have to stop chasing and start asking who set the course.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2004-2014): This was supposed to be the decade of finding themselves. Instead, it was the decade of surviving. This cohort graduated into reasonable job markets, then watched the 2008 crisis incinerate everything. They took jobs they were overqualified for, moved back home or crammed into apartments with four roommates, watched friends who'd done everything right end up bartending and driving for Uber. The life script their parents followed (graduate, get job, get married, buy house, have kids) wasn't available at any price. They delayed everything. Not because they weren't ready—because the math didn't work.

The 30s (2014-2024): This decade was about picking up the pieces. They probably made more money than they did at 25, but it didn't feel like more. Rent went up. Groceries went up. The goalposts moved while they were running. They watched Gen Z enter the workforce with TikTok side hustles and no expectation of stability, and they weren't sure if Gen Z was smarter than they'd been or more broken. They were supposed to 'settle down,' but settled felt like a trap. They built something—they just weren't sure what.

The 40s (2024-2034): This cohort is entering this decade now. Statistically, this will be peak earning period. They'll have authority at work, clarity about what they want, maybe some acceptance of what they can't change. If they have kids, kids will be getting older, needing less of their physical presence and more of their wisdom (such as it is). Their parents will be aging, needing more. They'll be sandwiched—managing up and down, responsible for generations on either side. Some will double down on the life they've built. Some will blow it up and start over. Both choices are valid.

The 50s (2034-2044): They'll be pre-retirement age with no expectation of retiring. They'll have lived through at least four economic crises, probably two pandemics, and so many 'once in a generation' events that the phrase lost meaning years ago. They'll mentor younger people who can't imagine a world before smartphones, and they'll catch themselves saying things like 'you don't understand' and hating how they sound. They'll be annoyed at their naivety and jealous of it in equal measure.

The 60s and beyond (2044+): Retirement, if it exists for them, won't look like their grandparents' version—the pension, the gold watch, the decades of leisure. It'll be part-time work, gig economy participation, reliance on systems that may or may not still exist. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live. The world will be unrecognizable. And they'll tell younger people what it was like before the internet, before smartphones, before everything was connected. They'll tell them about Blockbuster Friday nights and dial-up modems and calling friends' houses. They won't believe them. It'll sound like science fiction in reverse.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US in 1984. This cohort is part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials—the largest living generation, at least for now. Gen Z is catching up.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): This cohort got the same degrees, but Gen X got jobs that paid enough to live on. Gen X bought houses in their twenties. This cohort is still renting in their forties. Gen X had pensions; this generation has 401(k)s and the vague hope that Social Security won't collapse before they're seventy. Gen X came of age during economic expansion; this cohort came of age in economic crater. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is notable. When Boomers were this cohort's age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. This cohort controls 7%. A house in 1975 cost about two years of median income. Boomers bought their forever home at 28 and watched it appreciate 400% while they slept. They got pensions—actual guaranteed retirement income. This generation got 401(k)s and the vague hope that Social Security survives.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): This cohort remembers the before times. Gen Z doesn't. This cohort still believes, somewhere deep down, that the system can be reformed. Gen Z knows it's broken and are building around it. This cohort adapted to smartphones as young adults; Gen Z was born with iPads in their hands. This cohort has nostalgia; Gen Z has nihilism. Neither has savings.

Life expectancy for this generation is 78-80 years—slightly lower than previous generations, thanks to rising deaths from suicide, overdose, and alcoholism. This generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before, which is treated as a personal failing rather than a rational response to irrational conditions.

But this generation has also made the world genuinely better. They normalized therapy. They destigmatized mental health struggles. They pushed for marriage equality and racial justice and trans rights in ways their parents' generation refused to. They inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. The economy is rigged against them, but the culture shifted because they showed up. That matters.

year_events: Apple Macintosh launched with iconic '1984' Super Bowl ad
Ronald Reagan re-elected in landslide victory
Band Aid recorded 'Do They Know It's Christmas?'
